That's the ticket, Jiminy Cricket!
You hold up your end, and we'll hold up ours. We're behind you, 100%!

(oops, that almost went out as 100$)

This is too much to ask of most people!
Most people can only accept that what is morally bad cannot be effective. They must believe that "crime does not pay".

The trend described started before texting, social media and even the internet. My hunch is it's correlated to advances in gender equality, which is obviously a good thing. Some might miss the good old days, but the new thing suits others better.

No, pointing out sexism doesn't make the term less credible.
I don't think that talking about clothes at an event that works hard to feature them is "politicizing".

Playing the sexism card on the Red Carpet???? Really?!  Throwing the term "sexism" around so much causes it to lose its inherent credibility.  The author also loses her credibility for politicizing a Hollywood award show.

"MIKE HALE: Christoph Waltz, Damian Lewis, Adele: the accents are ahead so far."

Um -- you do realize this is the _foreign_ press awards.

I don't care what his numbers are, I don't know of another player whose swing was as smooth and effortless as McGriff's. That upper deck shot into the night sky at Yankee Stadium when he was a Blue Jay...wow...that is one of the defining baseball memories of my youth.
Japan has almost four times California's population of 35 million.
"Japan has a long history of financial stability" - Really?  Try telling that to anyone who bought Japanese stocks or real estate back in 1989 at the peak of the bubble.
Uh, Japan's population of Japan is over three times that of California, which is less than 40 million.

Japan has some advantages over the US when it comes to economic policy. To start with the population is 127,817,277. That is less than the population of California. It is also heterogeneous with very little social deviations. Even in politics, with opposition parties you do not see the acrimony that you see in our congress.

Until recently when you got a job with a company, it was a lifetime job. From my perspective the Japanese are stoic and make the best of what they have. They seem to have lost their lead in the electronics industry for now, but still lead in the automotive. In the 1970s they took the steel industry from the US. While the American steel companies were complacent and failed to investing new technology, Japan began making steel better, more efficiently and faster and faster.

The Japanese tried investing in the US at just the wrong time and lost quite heavily; that has made them cautious. Even so, several large companies in Japan are profitable and growing. Japanese companies pay their dividends annually or biannually which allows them to avoid the pressure of the quarterly reports that most American stockholders demand, and they do not have the corporate raiders we have.

Japan has a long history of financial stability, and it appears it will continue to do so.

I like to think that the growing sense of disorganization in our cultural narrative IS the story to tell.  If "Memento" is a parable for our times, can we look deeply into current storytelling dynamics beyond condemning the resulting symptoms such as frantically seeking wonder?  Maybe the addictive quest for stimulation in isolation points to the failure of some cherished beliefs about what holds society together.  We live in a very uncomfortable time that has seen the reliability of our cultural ideals largely demolished.   Isolation doesn't seem too far-fetched a consequence. In our country, perhaps a pregnant chaos must precede a new American Dream made of entirely different stuff.

This article is disappointing -- placing total (over) emphasis on the differences ion ethnic make-up the TAG and non-TAG programs -- and barely discussing the actual tests or explaining how the system works If the tests are biased, DOCUMENT this and explain how, with evidence, don't just spread innuendo!

There ARE a lot of things to complain about in the way the City handles public education -- in particular, the denial of adequate funds for school construction and upkeep (too few seats and dilapidated buildings in many schools) and for funding for programs shifting the load to to the PTAs of schools (thus making more affluent districts better able to pay for "enrichment" programs); the skewing of money from PUBLIC schools to privately-run charter schools; and the ongoing trashing the teaching profession. But oddly, the Times doesn't seem too interested in investigating THOSE issues. The question could/should be asked "why?"

And there ARE a lot of valid objections to the idea of the increasing emphasis on testing as a criteria for admissions to these programs (and for others), often the only criteria, and to the Byzantine process that now exists, which is hard to navigate for parents and stressful for kids. WHY not explore THOSE aspects?

And all those objections (and many others) noted, how about discussing how a BETTER system might look? The idea that things would be better if TAG programs were run by cronyistic local school boards is risible.

As an educator and advocate for children's services/accomodations, just as we have special supports it's only logical to offer the same for children in which mainstream education is not challenging enough. I read the article. It's not about race. It's about ability and providing full spectrum education. Good for you! Keep pressing on and challenging these kiddos!! Sounds like some are using this as a means to focus on socioeconomic status. If you feel your child is being left out or secluded, pick a more adequate school/program for your child's needs. And please attempt to be realistic about your child's abilities. Some are academically inclined... Others will struggle to get through and will find they are more talented functioning members of society in the entertainment or working world. Bell curve.

Smarter parents? What a brilliant solution! How did we fail to see it?

Seriously, if that is where your "solution" stops it isn't a solution. It is a justification for letting other peoples kids go down the drain.

We have a responsibility to ALL of today's children to give them everything they need to grow up to become the smartest parents they can become.

Even the smartest parents are stupid sometimes. Depending largely on the station in life into which they were born those stupid moments can be fatal or inconsequential for their kids. A democratic society would organize its schools to do everything to compensate for those inequities. A commitment to maximizing human potential demands nothing less.

"Wouldn't the positive role modelling offered by the gifted students help those less gifted?"

Gifted kids deserve to be academically challenged and advanced at school. That's the purpose of school.
"Helping others" is called community service. It's important and worthy, but it isn't the job of a gifted child to perform community service at school.

If anything, always being placed in the "helper" role is a sure-fire way to teach a child that he/she is superior to those needing help and is far more likely to give them an "over-inflated" sense of themselves. Being challenged academically is far more likely to be humbling.

"A string of mostly white faces and then a line of mostly black and Hispanic ones walked down the hall….critics contend...standards favor white or Asian, over black and Hispanic children …"

Let's begin with the obvious: Race is a physical identification and the word Hispanic is NOT. It's impossible to look a student's face and identify the student as racially Hispanic. Yet, in the 6 pages it took to write this verbose article, the reader is consistently accosted with the reinforcement of the FALSE premise--that the word Hispanic means a racial classification physically distinct from white students, black students, and Asian students. Journalist's need to do their due dilligence and not negligently reinforce and promote a false racial premise.

And then there is the not so obvious--the constant reinforcement of the premise-- if labeled Hispanic then must be lower than middle class. Latin Americans come in upper, middle, and lower class and it would be ridiculous and bigoted to reinforce the association with only low class, yet this is exactly what this article is doing. So, what then should the NYT journalist have done? Well, to begin with: interview the children labeled Hispanic, and find out exactly what their race is; then, if they are immigrants: legal or illegal, then what their days are like, then, ... there IS much more to to ask, however, there is not enough space here to elaborate more. To be sure, all it takes is more due diligence and less political games.

Why do many people automatically accept the proposition that children across races have, as turbot stated below, "equal potentials at birth," when there is so much evidence to the contrary? (Note: if you disagree there is evidence of this, look up "race and intelligence" on Wikipedia; if you do not view Wikipedia as reliable, check nearly any unbiased source that has methodologically rigorous studies)

For anyone that does not insist on sticking his or her head in the sand, it is obvious there are innate differences between *self-identified* racial groups under a number of different measurements of IQ. Now, there are numerous arguments meant to distract and deflect ("inability to define race groups," "inability to define intelligence," "expectation or priming bias (where certain subgroups perform worse because they believe they are suppose to)"--but these arguments do not hold up to full scrutiny. I recognize it would be better for me to post a complete list of references here, but there is not space (please spend even 5 minutes researching the topics with an open mind if you are skeptical).

What infuriates me about this issue is that we as a society are not able to most effectively address and ameliorate these issues if we continue to pretend that such differences do not exist--we are hurting those that are ostensibly helped by our willful ignorance.

Finally, please note that this is not placing value judgments on individuals' worths, but understanding how best to help.

As someone who benefited from gifted classes, my only concern is that those kids who truly are gifted won't get the opportunity to grow. Don't mix "ungifted" kids with the gifted, or all you'll get is frustrated, bored bright kids.

My above (perhaps now below, not certain) comments regarding my 6 year old daughter, who scored 100% on 5th grade math tests (right after she turned 6), yes that's not just bright, but gifted. We have no money for any special tutors or classes to send our daughter.

Further, there's a question of desire and motivation to learn as well. Perhaps there are children from less privileged households (gee, like mine), that could benefit from, and thrive in, a G & T program. Can a child think in terms of 3-dimensional space? Can a child get 100%, or close to it, on tests from at least 2, if not 4, grade levels above them? Perhaps certain schools need to re-visit the definition of "gifted".

How can we possibly bring up the performance levels of those who are far from gifted, while trying to keep those who truly are gifted, in the same classes? Okay, multiply 4 digits by 4 digits, accurately solve in head and state answer. Classmates doing 5 + 6 = 11. Where is the commonality or overlap of work being performed?

The children who can barely do the first grade work, certainly aren't going to gain anything just from the experience of being in the same classroom as my daughter. Doesn't the obvious disparity in talent already cause enough trouble? Does one actually think that the same classroom, with dramatically less abled peers, won't lead to playground bullying performed upon the more gifted, by those who are far from it? Is this the "level" being sought after?

What does diversity have to do with education? It's a shame how the chips fall, but these are standardized tests, administered without bias and not even allowing the school principal to voice a preference as to who should be admitted. Invest money in pre natal and family counselling, early intervention and then see if the demographics of G&T program change. Even before OLSAT there was Stanford Binet which cost $200 per child which was administered by a licensed psychologist and the demographics were almost the same. We're talking about providing education to our children so that they can be ready for the future, and not for the Board of Ed to be satisfied with some inane reports that are not worth the paper they are printed on.

If you only realized how few parents get the kids up (many kids do this for themselves), feed them (almost no one does this in urban districts), get them to school on time (tardies are such a problem they are threatening the districts' federal funds) and send them with supplies (a chronic problem in low-income schools).
Because of this reality in predominantly low-income districts, savvy parents do have to put forth extra effort to get their kids something better in those districts.
Life rewards effort. Of course, no child is more worthy than another. But children with parents unafraid of effort will reap the benefits.

This is incorrect--it retards the gifted students' learning quite a bit to place them in "regular" classes. Though you teach, and I'm sure your intentions are good, this attitude contributes to a hobbling of our cerebral resources and human capital in the United States.

I'd be willing to wager that, while basic education is important to some extent, some very large segment of the population does not need the knowledge learned in secondary education. While it sounds blunt, the students that will have relatively large marginal impacts on the productivity in the United States (or globally) will generally be those classified as "gifted." In my mind, there is no reason to promote the education of those on the lower end of the spectrum at the expense of the most talented; while focusing on the slower students might satisfy some primal sense of fairness, it is not nearly as helpful to society to focus resources on students with a likely low level of return on educational resources.

Imagine this situation: you can choose in 4th grade to focus resources on someone who will ultimately be a secretary or one who will be some sort of scientist (a broad category admittedly)--which do you choose? The additional resources will likely not make the first much better (if at all) at being a secretary, but could easily make a large impact on the success of the second, and consequently the "value" returned to society. This is a simplification of a complex issue, but it's still relevant.

The huge problem you will find is that there aren't enough truly "gifted" students to form these classes--you would very quickly dilute the effects gained from the separation.

Even generously setting the definition to gifted at the top 5%, that's 5 students out of 100--hardly a high enough ratio to start dividing and using to improve the outcomes of the other students...

San Diegan--you are perpetuating a very harmful false belief that intelligence is not heritable. I have no idea why people assume this, other than it doesn't sound appealing from a "fairness" perspective.

Yes, motivated parents are important, but with estimates of heritability of intelligence as high as 70%, it's important to understand that there is almost certainly a very high genetic component as well.

I thought that we had moved beyond this.

Lewis Terman conducted research as early as 1926 that showed decisively that gifted students do best when in a modified curriculum contained in its own classroom. His work was at Stanford, and this was confirmed in the 1970s by work at Hopikins.

Enrichment is not sufficient to meet the educational needs of g/t students. i read at a 12 th grade level when i in 6th grade. Enrichment would not begin to challenge me at this point. I was ready for function/algebra in 5gh grade but didn't get it utnil 9th. Same point.

This point was setlled decades ago and needs no further debate.

A simple solution to the problem would be to: 1. Eliminate G&T classes for K-3 and 2. grant admissions to the top 5% in each school rather than city-wide. The brightest  (or at least best testing) 5% in East New York would go to school with the brightest 5% in Park Slope. College-educated white parents would be banging down the doors to send their kids to failing schools to improve their odds.

I don't completely understand this. I was in the SPE program starting in the seventh grade. The class was a challenge not just because of the workload but because we students commuted from all over Brooklyn to go to it at JHS 296. But, the class was mixed. Some Whites, some Blacks and some Asians. How did it become so full of one race?

Perhaps some research is in order. Instead of throwing out phrases meant to blame another segment of the population, you should look into the studies on heritability of intelligence.

These studies control for race and income.
